briefOverview: The revelation identifies Independence, Missouri, as the center of Zion and assigns concrete temporal and ecclesiastical tasks to establish the gathering place.
summary: The Lord designates Missouri as the land of promise and Independence as the center place for the city of Zion, marking a nearby site west of the courthouse for a temple. The saints are instructed to purchase lands, especially westward and by the prairies, as an everlasting inheritance. Sidney Gilbert is appointed to act as the church’s agent, receive funds, open an honest store, obtain a license, and use proceeds to buy land and supply the saints. Edward Partridge is to divide inheritances among the saints, with his appointed helpers; William W. Phelps is to serve as the church’s printer, with Oliver Cowdery assisting in copying, correcting, and selecting materials by the Spirit. Those named are to settle in Zion swiftly with their families, and the bishop and agent are to prepare for the arrival and settlement of additional families. Further directions for the rest of the elders and members will follow later.
externalContext: This revelation was given in July 1831 in Independence, Jackson County, Missouri, a frontier town near the western border of the state. The 1830 Indian Removal Act had recently led to the creation of Indian Territory immediately west of Missouri, shaping local commerce and land pressures. Church leaders and missionaries had been directed earlier that year to travel to Missouri, anticipating further light about Zion’s location. On the frontier, acquiring land, establishing licensed mercantile operations, and setting up a printing press were essential to community formation and legal standing. The individuals named—Edward Partridge (bishop), Sidney (A.) Gilbert (agent/merchant), William W. Phelps (printer), and Oliver Cowdery (scribe/assistant)—were already emerging leaders with distinct administrative and publishing responsibilities.
externalReferences: The phrase “those who sit in darkness and in the region and shadow of death” echoes biblical language (Matthew 4:16; cf. Luke 1:79), framing the mercantile and publishing efforts as supports to preaching the gospel. Edward Partridge had previously been called and ordained as bishop (Doctrine and Covenants 41:9), and this section reiterates his role in distributing inheritances. Sidney Gilbert had earlier been designated an agent to the church (Doctrine and Covenants 53:4), and William W. Phelps had been called to printing and related labors, including assisting with copying and correcting materials (Doctrine and Covenants 55:4). Later revelations reaffirm the Missouri temple site and the New Jerusalem in that region (Doctrine and Covenants 84:3–4).
practicalQuestions: How can I practice transparent, honest commerce that directly supports spiritual aims and community needs?
In what ways can I accept and magnify an assigned stewardship, even if it is primarily administrative or temporal?
What resources should our community acquire or develop now to sustainably support growth and worship?
How do I balance speed in responding to divine direction with prudence and righteousness in execution?
How can publishing, communication, and resource distribution better enable preaching to those “who sit in darkness”?
uncertainAreas: The precise meaning of “the line running directly between Jew and Gentile” (v. 4) is not explicit; it may allude to a geopolitical boundary of the time. The scope and permanence of “everlasting inheritance” may be covenantal rather than strictly legal. The nature of the “license” for Sidney Gilbert (v. 9) is not specified. The timing implied for constructing the temple and fully building the city of Zion is not detailed here.
